workflow.name: Weekly OKR alignment report with Gmail, Google Calendar, Notion, and GPT-4.1
workflow.description:
## How it works

This workflow is your personal **CEO Brain**. Every Saturday night, it automatically collects the past week‚Äôs activity across:

- üì© Gmail: filters out spam, promos, receipts, etc.  
- üìÖ Google Calendar: grabs past week and upcoming month  
- üóíÔ∏è Notion Weekly Plan: pulls and analyzes a photo of your weekly plan (e.g., taken from a paper planner/notebook) using GPT-4o  
- üéØ Notion OKRs: fetches quarterly OKRs and formats them for summary

It sends all the data to GPT-4.1, which generates a smart weekly report ‚Äî including progress check, misalignments, overdue follow-ups, and next steps ‚Äî then emails it to you as a **Weekly OKR Report**.

---

## Set up steps

- üß† Add your Gmail, Google Calendar, Notion, and OpenAI credentials  
- üìÖ The Notion Weekly Plan should have a **date property** and an **image field** that holds a photo of your planner/notebook page  
- üéØ The Notion OKR database should include **objective**, **key result**, and **status** fields  
- üîÅ Schedule is preset to **every Saturday at 20:30 HK time** (cron `0 30 20 * * 6`). Also set the **workflow timezone in n8n** and, if self-hosting, the **server/container TZ** (e.g., `TZ=Asia/Hong_Kong`) to ensure correct triggering  
- üí¨ You can modify the AI prompts inside the LLM nodes for more customized outputs

nodes.name: Filter1
nodes.notes:
On the last day of each week, the system grabs the weekly plan of that week. 

{{ $now.setZone('Asia/Hong_Kong').toISODate() }}

nodes.name: Weekly Code

values.content:
=# Inputs ## OKRs {{ $node["Quarterly Code"].json["okrs_joined"] }} ## Calendar {{ $node["Calendar Code"].json["calendar_joined"] }} ## Weekly Plan {{ $node["Weekly Code"].json["weeklyplan_joined"] }} ## Emails {{ $node["Gmail Code"].json["emails_joined"] }} # Tasks 1. Check alignment across OKRs, emails, calendar, and weekly plan. * Treat OKRs as the North Star. * Use emails, calendar events, and weekly plan tasks as evidence of actual work. * Look for alignment (e.g., a weekly task reflected in an email thread). * Also recognize complementary items (e.g., a short task that appears only on weekly plan but not blocked on calendar). * Goal: form a comprehensive view of progress. 2. Assess execution realism for the week. * Highlight over- or under-scheduling, conflicts, missing preparation, and dependencies. * Identify what advances each OKR, and flag any OKRs falling behind due to lack of attention or communication. * Call out gaps and risks (e.g., a key result with no calendar time or email activity, or a due date approaching). 3. Extract time-sensitive asks and commitments from emails. * Note replies that are delayed or missing. * Highlight urgent follow-ups to avoid overlooking important threads. 4. Suggest concrete next steps. * Recommend actions that keep execution realistic and OKRs on track. # Output format Return the entire output as valid HTML (no Markdown). Follow this structure:

Summary

  • 4‚Äì6 key themes of the week.

Alignment Check

OKR Weekly Plan Tasks Calendar Events Related Emails / Notes

Email Follow-ups

  • List urgent or overdue responses

Next Steps

  1. 3‚Äì5 clear actions for the coming week

You are an assistant that checks alignment across OKRs, emails, calendar, and weekly plans. 
Always return valid HTML (no Markdown). 
Treat OKRs as the North Star for evaluation.
Maintain realistic scope.
    * Remember you are an assistant tool with limited background context.
    * Avoid making unsupported assumptions or inventing details.
    * High-level or abstract insights are still valuable.

data.details: The Code node allows you to execute JavaScript in your workflow.

The Filter node can be used to filter items based on a condition. If the condition is met, the item will be passed on to the next node. If the condition is not met, the item will be omitted. Conditions can be combined together by AND(meet all conditions), or OR(meet at least one condition).
